docs.lead_paragraph: President Reagan wants Congress to authorize a modest charge for medical care given to poor people under the Medicaid program and has also decided to seek further reductions in the Federal subsidy for school lunches. Officials at the White House and the Agriculture Department said that the President had decided to seek elimination of the subsidy for school lunches served to ''nonpoor'' children. There are more than 11 million such children, those from families with incomes exceeding 185 percent of the poverty standard. That standard, for a family of four, is $8,414 a year.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times
